title: Ontology Search: An Empirical Evaluation

author: Anila Sahar Butt, College of Engineering and Computer Science, Australian National University

segmentation: In today's talk, I will talk about the motivation behind ranking ontologies and the need for the benchmark.
Then I will introduce CBR bench next.
I will report some observation based on the experiments conducted in CBR pinch.
And finally we will report some recommendations that we believe can enhance the performance of ranking algorithms.
So let's start with the motive.
And as we all know, that ontology is a formal, explicit specification of a shared conceptualization without.
Minimal shared conceptualization.
The benefit of having an ontology is limited.
Therefore, most of the ontology engineers, while designing their ontology.
They actually reused some existing and authentic conceptualization.
However, the key ingredient while building an ontology is to discover the right ontology or ontology call term.
There are many search engines that are available to find existing ontologies an intelligible terms.
Um?
And they are index existing ontologies or into logical terms and retrieve the relevant results for the user based on a simple keyword query or more advanced fisted search.
Portal is one of the ontology search engine that.
Index of ontologies and retrieve list of relevant results for the user.
Open vocabulary is another initiative of ontology search engines.
As we can see that for the author Curie, it retrieves more than 1600 results and when there are there are so many results for the single Curie.
Then it becomes an accessory for the ontology search engines to retreat to apply some ranking algorithms to effectively fulfill the user's information need.
However.
The ranking of ontologies in ontological terms is a nontrivial task.
There are many challenges involved in this, for example in and a concept can be defined in multiple ontologies in different perspective.
Let's take example of person in for photology person models the.
Models the social behavior of of person, whereas in another ontology appearance person models the physical appearance of of human being.
Secondly, a concept can be defined in multiple ontology in same perspective but in different level of details.
One ontology explain a define our concept at abstract level while other ontology defined the same concept concept in more detail.
And then there is another aspect of reuse, an extension, a concept is defined in one of the ontology and the other ontologies use an extend this concept to model more features.
No, the question for the ontology search engine is how to ring a classes in properties with different level of modeling details.
There are different document retrieval ranking algorithms and graph based ranking algorithms that has been extensively used to run on the task of ranking ontologies.
However, there is no standard way to.
To evaluate the effectiveness of.
Thinking algorithms, therefore, for the reason we present, CBR bench schonbrunn Teologi Rinking benchmark.

The constituents of CBR bench includes ontology, collection of benchmark curries are ground truth established by human experts and effectiveness of a baseline ranking that is established from the effectiveness of eight state of the art ranking models.
First talk we will talk about ontology collection.
We use the namespace is registered at prefix dot CC as a seed said for our ontology collection.
We crawled all the registers, registered namespaces and for every successfully retrieved ontology.
If we followed the.
Import statement sandwich.
Retrieved all imported ontologies until no new ontologies are added in ontology collection.
In this way we come up with 1020 two different ontologies an or in our ontology collection.
All in all describe 5.5 million triples, 280,000 classes and seven point 5000 properties.
Next is a benchmark duties to design our benchmark.
Curious, we looked into the log search log of link open vocabulary search engine.

We ranked the search terms according to their popularity in the search log, and then for each popular term, we looked into the ontology collection that if we have at least 10 relevant results for for that Curie.
Benchmark duties and their popularity in the linked open vocabulary search engine is shown on the table.
All of our benchmark curries are single keyword Curry because of the two main reason.
Only 11% of the search log.
Linked open vocabulary search log contains compound Curie curious an none of the compound Curie was among 200.
Top keyword search queries.
Secondly, for none of the compound Curie in top 1000.
1000 search results search.
Terms we had enough relevant resources in ontology collection to come up with a meaningful ranking.
After this we established our ground truth.
We conducted a study within ontology engineer experts.
For that, we first selected a candidate search for each Curie to select the candidate set.
We consider that if a Uri contains the part of if you are I contains Ecurie term or or.

Curie as we can see that fourth person is on the top and then we have all these.
All these resources according to their relevance.

Ground truth is established.
We have benchmark yurizan we have ontology collection.
We try to establish our baseline ranking an for that we consider 8 ranking algorithms.
They belong to a document retrieval model document ranking models or the graph based ranking models.
But they have been extensively used for the task of ontology ranking.
We can broadly categorize.
We broadly categorize these two these.
8 ranking algorithms into two groups.
Content based ranking models and graph based ranking models where content based ranking models only considered the content of the resource in graph based ranking model.
Consider the structure and nature of the resources within an ontology.
Base.
Nine ranking performance of these algorithm is shown in this slide.
We can see that the TF IDF is best performing ranking model from content based ranking algorithms and between us mayor is the best ranking model from graph based ranking models.
However, if we look into the overall performance, we can see that mean average precision for.
For TF, IDF, an normalized discounted cumulative gain for the TF IDF is better than other ranking models, and they are actually the performance of TF.
IDF is actually more stable than Aura ranking models on our ontology collection.
Based on the experiments we conducted in evaluate the performance of the ranking model, we come up with some observation and the observations are content based ranking model like TF.
IDF slightly outperformed graph based ranking models.
And most importantly, the intuition behind document retrieval algorithm does not fit on does not match to the ontology retrieval.
For example for TF IDF idea intuition is that if a word appear more in the documents, then is less relevant to or is less important to a particular document, while in ontology.
If our if our resource appears in multiple ontologies, that is, it is reused in many ontologies.
So is probably the important concept for an ontology.
Both of these wrong intuition weaken.
The 4th person didn't appear in Top 10 results for for TF IDF because it was in our ontology collection.
It was in 162 ontologies.
Because of that it got a lower score.
But the idea was used as vector space model.
An TF IDF was used as a weights in vector space model and BM25 and so they inherit the wrong intuition of TF IDF.
Nexus PM 25.
Frank ranks document entology higher.

This is because of the reason that domain ontology contains many concept similar to a relative to a particular domain, and if many concept of a particular domain matches to the query term, they add up to the relevance score of the ontology an.
Finally it got a higher rank.
Next, density measure models mostly ranked upper level ontologies higher in the search results.
This is because of the reason that density measure counts the number of links attached to a particular concept in the ontology.
However, for complex hierarchies the terms are.
Terms contains lots of superclasses and subclasses, and because of that these ontologies get higher rank.
In the search result, finally, the graph based models like page rank in density measure because they only consider relationships or links irrespective of their relevance to the Curie term.
Therefore sometimes it come up with a very poor recall, sorry, precision.
Semantic similarity measure considers the shortest path of two match terms in an ontology.
And this model becomes irrelevant if in case of single keyword kerryann single match resources in an ontology.
However, we believe that for multi keyword query or compound curious semantic similarity measure could have performed much better.

Ranking models based on term label alone results in poor performance as expected, because, like class, matchmaker is least performing ranking model and this is because of the reason that it consider only it's consider only label of resources an for address Curie.
The two resources Postal address and the email address of specimen is they both are considered as partial match in class match measure and they got the same relevant score.
However, one of the resources relevant to the query, while the other resources irrelevant.
Based on our observations, we propose for recommendations that we believe can enhance the effectiveness of ranking models.
The first is intent type versus context type of resource as.
Intended type, for example, in a resource name of the person.
Intent type is name and person is a context resource, so this resource matched to two different curries.
Benchmark Yuri's name in person and human experts.
They evaluate this resources as extremely useful or useful for name Curie but slightly useful or irrelevant for the person Curie.
However, none of the ranking algorithm take this into consideration, and because of that all the ranking models they assign same relevance score to this resource for both the queries.
Next, the second recommendation is that we believe that if Curie semantics for partial matches is considered, then we can improve the performance.
For example, when we consider partial mash, four person Curie personal is is a match of person, and dislocation is a match of location.
However, according to the user experience evaluation, personal is relevant.
However, dislocation is irrelevant results because of the reason that this.
Model did not consider the sense of a word or since match between word and the keyword and the resource, and they only consider the label apart.
Find and then there is the relevant relations versus context relations.

Most of the Gravis ranking algorithms they take into account or all the links according to the algorithm according to the model, and they do not take into account the relevant relations or irrelevant relation.
For example, the email address in over ontology.
It has many properties, but few of the properties are shown on this slide, but.
Because of we can see that these properties are not very related to email address.
However, because of the number of edges attached to the resource, this concept get a higher relevance score to the address Curie.
Then finally, there is.
We believe that if we rank the resources.
For a particular Curie, rather than ranking an ontology for a particular Curie.
It can enhance the performance of ranking algorithm and this can be seen in TF IDF where a particular resource was was ranked only for a query term and not the complete ontology.
So here is the CBR benchling.
I hope that you can try it and you will find it useful, thank you.
